Context background
This project is targeted at learners with fewer opportunities who are carrying out vocational training in catering, horticulture, construction and enterprise. Many of these learners face barriers to learning and accessing work which their peers do not. They require an additional intervention in order to succeed and improve their future career and learning prospects. The lead partner is The Platform who are part of a consortium of sending partners including Sussex Downs College, Brooklands College and Chichester College. They will be sending learners to the host partners Eco Chateau in France, CESIE in Italy and Stadsgarage in Holland.
Objectives
We will work with learners with fewer opportunities to support them with an additional intervention to build their confidence, skills and broaden their horizons. The objectives of the project will address their issues and needs through:
-Providing additional assessment and support opportunities to validate skills for learners to succeed in their qualifications
-Boosting employability and mobility in the wider EU labour market through practical work experience
-Raising participant's awareness and understanding of other cultures, countries and language to broaden their life perspective
-Increasing self-esteem, confidence and motivation and social skills
Accompanying adults will have opportunities for continued professional development, increasing their motivation in working with groups with fewer opportunities and will develop their teaching to include transnational perspectives.
The partners also aim to work together to modernise education and training in working with these groups by sharing best practice and utilizing innovative techniques in supporting learners with fewer opportunities to improve their learning performance and enhance the employability and mobility prospects. The project will also reinforce and further develop the transnational scope of the partner organisations in working at an international level.

Number and profile of participants
Participants will be aged 16 - 65 with fewer opportunities studying vocational qualifications in the vocational areas of horticulture, catering, construction and enterprise.  Most learners will also have additional needs such as learning disabilities, mental health issues, housing issues, disengagement from society, low educational attainment, offending and drug and alcohol issues. The total number of learners who will participate in the project is 322 with 96 accompanying adults. This will be carried out over 28 mobility flows with an average of 11.5 learners and 3.5 accompanying adults per group”.

Description of project activities
Two week work placements will take place at host partner organisations in the vocational areas of catering, horticulture, construction and enterprise. The placement itinerary will be jointly designed by course tutors from sending partner organisations and the host partner to build in opportunities for vocational and personal development objectives specific to the participants. Outside of the working day, visits will be organised to places relevant to their vocational areas such as to local food producers and visits to building projects. Participants will also take part in cultural visits to places of interest, socialise with local people and share a meal in the local community. 

Methodology used in carrying out the project
The project will be managed within the Care Co-ops Quality and Project Management Framework. For mobility projects, this includes the 10 principles of the European Quality Charter for Mobility. 

Results and impact envisaged
The expected impact of the project on the learners is that they will have increased opportunities for their learning outcomes to be assessed, therefore increasing their opportunities to succeed in achieving their qualifications. We also expect that participants will demonstrate increased confidence, motivation, linguistic and employability skills through having carried out a work placement abroad. Consortium and partner organisations will share good practice through established networks and this will contribute to a larger dialogue about creative ways to engage learners with fewer opportunities and additional needs through mobility projects. Accompanying staff will develop their professional skills in sharing practice with consortium and partner organisations and experience increased motivation as a result. 

Potential long term benefits
In the long term we expect the project to have a significant impact on the learners' attitude towards work, learning and European work to increase their future prospects. Through further developing this model, we hope to share our learning more widely so that it can be adopted by other organisations for inclusion in future European mobility experiences.

How did this project idea come about?

'Building Sustainable Communities with VET 2' expands on a current project that brings together B3st’s ambitions in providing relevant placements at organisations who work sustainably with communities in Andalusia, Spain. It recognises the need for participants to gain work experience that is increasingly difficult to obtain in order to develop their career. The placements in Spain will add great value by offering a supportive environment for participants to gain new industry insights, become proficient in a language other than English and appreciate another European culture. 

Who is this project aimed at?

The project duration is one year and will accommodate a total of 72 participants over two years. Its participants will typically be learners working towards vocational qualifications in the field of community development and education. We anticipate they will be between the ages of 18 and 25 and come from various backgrounds, often with limited opportunities to gain necessary work experience.  The three month mobility will be formally recognised with participants completing vocational certificates from the Learning Resource Network. 

What are the objectives?

Our main aim is to provide VET learners with relevant work experience in community engagement to develop their careers. We hope to give participants:

• A practical understanding of work at a relevant organisation that engages communities using a sustainable approach
• Enhanced employability skills that demonstrate workplace experience and adaptability 
• Personal and professional development with intercultural and linguistic skills
• The opportunity to network and build up contacts in the relevant field
• The platform to progress in their chosen career or embark upon further education in their sector

What activities will the participants do?

The main activity involves a work placement of three months at either Centris English School, Cooperacion Internacional, CSIC, EcoEduca, Ecologistas en Acción, Save the Children or 3Si. This will be complemented by linguistic support from qualified tutors and a programme of cultural and social activities, including organised language exchanges. The participants will be supported throughout the lifetime of the project with clearly defined stages, from mobility preparation to evaluation. Our mentoring and monitoring processes will aim to address the development and well-being of participants during their placement while informing project evaluation. 

What is your project methodology?

The project’s methodology provides a framework to support VET learners in developing skills acquired in the workplace as they work alongside experienced professionals in their chosen sector. Through our experience with past European mobility projects and our employer partnerships, we have developed and applied appropriate processes and instruments to ensure the project can be effectively managed and evaluated while providing support to participants for their personal and professional progression. 

What are the anticipated impacts of the project?

We anticipate that the project will make a positive impact on all its 72 participants by giving them the opportunity to develop professional and personal skills at a relevant work placement. Based on past projects, the experience should increase the participants’ employment prospects while also giving them confidence to apply for work across Europe. It is expected that at least two thirds of participants will move into suitable employment upon completion of the placement, with a further one fifth progressing into continued related training. 

The three month placement in Seville, together with linguistic support, should increase the participants’ Spanish language proficiency by one CEFR level. The project will also impact on our partners by building their capacity to participate in further Erasmus+ programmes and European projects. The focus on sustainable communities should encourage participants and partners to consider and continue building a sustainable future for European society, reflecting Europe 2020 objectives. 

How do you expect project partners will benefit in the long term?

Project outcomes will feed back into our own work as a VET college, our established partner relationships and employer networks, such as the Brighton Sustainable Business Network. It will benefit our development of European-centred vocational training and planned KA1 and KA2 projects in the field. Our relationship with partners that have wider networks will facilitate dissemination activities with the intention of building sustainability into professional approaches and organisation operations; closing the gap between VET provision and the world of work; and fostering a more informed understanding of the needs of jobseekers and employers in community development.
The Impact of social entrepreneurship and social rights on African Diaspora Youth Workers - Training for trainers for African Diaspora Youth Workers

With the involvement of african youth workers will get different partner organizations work together for the benefit of youth workers that are facing unemployment situation and for the benefit of communities living in disadvantage neighborhoods through social rights support coming from the african youth workers. It will also increase the sense of belonging of african youth workers to the local societies where they will being providing support of social entrepreneurship.

The objectives of this project: 
- To train youth workers, trainers, young leaders active in African organisations in social rights, to raise their knowledge of right.
- Exchange of good practice and real cases of young immigrant groups, working together on solutions and social actions, with the knowledge of social rights
- To work on recommendations to reduce social problems within disadvantaged neighborhoods and to exchange with stakeholders from Austria. 
- To train youth workers and trainers active in their local community in social entrepreneurship.
- To develop and promote management skills of the participants for the optimization of human resources, financial and logistics.
- To understand the importance of social entrepreneurship and social rights for creating value and enhancing the image of the organization.

The training mobility will be held in order to make sure that 38 youth worker participants from 16 partner countries will get more capacity to understanding well how the social entrepreneurship projects and social rights in each partner country and how it can be useful to support people that live in disadvantage neighborhoods. Multiplier events will be added values, with locals seminars to understand the community social impact. These local seminars are continuous learning process meeting of African youth workers which aims to bring together youth workers with African origin in a single space to share their local experiences. - Follow-up of Youth workers Mobility: Evaluation, Dissemination and exploitation of results. Evaluation, Dissemination and exploitation of results will be linked with multipliers events, but also with other international meetings. This moment will allow the partners and 23 experts and youth workers from partner countries involved to cooperate and promote/publicity this youth workers mobility project. One of the main purpose of follow-up is mentoring programme that will be leaded by UNIDO and Austria Development Agency experts. It will be great moment of progressive learning and useful to spread the best practices of project in the social entrepreneurship and rights fields.

We believe that this project will help to develop a whole set skills in african youth workers as participants identified and explained earlier to improve their abilities in the intervention of social rights and social entrepreneurship. "HRe-activism against Hate Speech" (HRvsHS) is a Training Course for human rights youth activism against hate speech, online and offline, addressing young trainers, youthworkers, activists and youth leaders, developing skills and competencies, acquiring online and offline tools, exploring produced materials for campaigning and exchanging best practices about counterring hate speech, based on “No Hate Speech Movement” Campaign experiences.

The Training Course will involve 26 participants from 12 countries, Albania, Armenia, Belgium, Georgia, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, Macedonia,  Serbia, Turkey  and United Kingdom and will take place in Italy, in the city of Reggio Calabria, on 16-23.09.2017, in occasion of  the European Action Day against Islamophobia.

The “No Hate Speech Movement” is a Council of Europe youth Campaign, implemented in 2013-2015 and prolonged until 2017. The campaign is against the expressions of hate speech online in all its forms, including those that most affect young people, such as forms of cyber-bullying and cyber-hate. The campaign is based upon human rights education, youth participation and media literacy. It aims at reducing hate speech and at combating racism and discrimination in their online expression. The working methods are awareness raising, advocacy, and it also seeks for creative solutions. It is a campaign for action and intervention. The campaign equips young people and youth organizations with the competences necessary to recognize and act against such human rights violations.

During this Training Course we want to explore the history of the Movement at European level and its implementation in the countries of the project partners, discuss about the definition of "hate speech" and "hate crime", learn about Campaign tools, as the Bookmarks and the Hate Speech Watch, share best practices and "counternarrative" techniques, using non formal learning methods and human right based approach.

Considering the alarming rise of online hate speech, of cyber-bullying phenomena which in some cases have even led to suicide of the victims, given the intensification of violent radicalization  and acts of terrorism, we believe essential to take action through education for the prevention and contrast of these phenomena, preparing adequately the youthworker through a high-level Training Course.

The increasing involvement of Italy in the Campaign, the strong experience and the good practices of the Partner Organizations, had inspired this Training Course, that want to take advantage of the reached goals, acquiring best practices and setting the bases of a stable cooperation with other national campaigns and groups of activists across Europe: during the final part of the project we will realize a public event, the NO HATE SPEECH DAY,  inviting institutions, trainers, youthwokers and young people from all the regions of Italy, to present the Campaign and testing what we learned during the TC, giving a practical demonstration of how to contrast hate speech online and offline.
VR Edu: Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality in the field of informal education

CONTEXT AND BACKGROUND

Our project aims to introduce and teach social and youth workers some of the usages of Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality in the context of informal education. Youth workers shall return from this training, with a strong awareness of existing tools in VR/AR and how these can be deployed in a youth work context at an affordable cost, so that participants may replicate or inspire themselves from the solutions we will have introduced during the training. 

Whilst the effectiveness of VR/AR has tools for learning has been demonstrated by academic research and in particular has shown to not only have a positive impact on learning and mental health, It’s usage in the field of youth organisations and non for profits has been lackluster. Lack of access to required equipment, and costs associated with VR/AR have been initial barriers of entry for many youth organisations. Yet rapidly falling costs of associated VR/AR equipment , and the emergence of existing VR / AR tools that work in conjunction with modern smartphones (e.g. Apple ARkit, Google’s ARcore, Unity and Google Cardboard) now allow youth organisations and non for profits to consider using VR/AR in their fields. This creates the perfect opportunity for youth workers to adopt VR / AR solutions for their field of work, our training aims to assist youth workers in acquiring the theoretical knowledge required to deploy these solutions.

Additional objectives of the project and how they fit EU policy are the following:

New learning opportunities for NEETS

Students who aren’t interested or aren’t regularly immersed in the learning process tend not to understand the subject properly, may experience delayed learning or even refuse to study at all. Finding ways to motivate students and specifically students identified as NEETS remains a crucial determinant of the quality of the learning process. Modern or innovative learning materials, including digital ones, are rarely much different than traditional textbooks. Most so-called advanced materials (such as MOOCS) don’t feature appealing visuals or truly interactive features, and are often perceived by students as boring. The usage of Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality offer the opportunity to try novel teaching methods on NEETS who might have disengaged from traditional teaching methods, VR / AR allow students to interact with computers in a brand new way, enabling creativity and additional interactivity.

Europe 2020 Objectives for smart growth

As part of the Europe 2020 strategy, the commission aims to bring economic growth within the EU partly by inciting innovation and fostering a digital society. Our project will be one of the means to help achieve these goals. Our program will empower youth workers with the skill set and knowledge necessary for them to collaborate with youths. The usage of VR / AR  in a youth work context, is likely to enhance creativity, innovation and leadership within youths themselves, as well as introduce youths to creative and productive usages of the VR / AR which could lead them to take an interest in a variety of related career fields including STEMS or media and arts related fields.

Increasing digital competencies 

VR / AR in particular offer particular avenues of growth for the economy, with estimate, research by IDC suggesting that the global market for VR and AR will be worth in excess of $162 billion by 2020. The scale and size of the market offers, employment opportunities for Europeans, yet current offers for training remains inadequate and limited to a niche number of individuals. Fostering digital competencies, remains one of the cornerstones of the commission's objective for 2020 and by offering training focussed on VR and AR to youth workers, we are offering training at the forefront of technological change, equipping youth workers with knowledge they can then transmit to youngsters themselves. 

PROJECT ACTIVITIES

We have several activities planned so far. We aim to split our training into main activities which are designed to reflect the current main technological solutions of the VR/AR market today. These include:

(1) Headset based VR activities
(2) Smartphone based VR activities
(3) Smartphone and tablet based AR activities
(4) 360 Video filming

IMPACT 

Some of the expected benefits of integrating VR/AR technology in youth work are :

- youth enjoy learning more, as they are actively involved, rather than passive listeners

- by grounding learning activities in an authentic, real-world context, VR/AR based experiences stimulate and engage learners. They learn to question things and to apply their natural curiosity to the real world

- VR/AR based learning methods promote social and communication skills by creating an environment that emphasizes collaboration and exchange of ideas.
Migrant young women entrepreneurship for social inclusion
AFRICAN CENTRE FOR DEVELOPMENT AND RESEARCH LTD

“Migrant young women entrepreneurship for social inclusion” project aims to promote entrepreneurship among young African migrant women as a way of facilitating their social inclusion. 
Young women from the African Diaspora are among the socially marginalized and disadvantaged youth groups in Europe. In order to facilitate the social inclusion of these young women, this project gathers 30 participants from African Diaspora organizations to exchange good practices on social entrepreneurship and social inclusion projects as well as train participants in gender mainstreaming and social participation. 
The social inclusion of migrant young women is a priority agenda for the participating organizations. Engagement through social projects is one way of enhancing the social participation, inclusion and integration of young migrant women. The project aims to provide incentives for young people to become empowered and strive to look for innovative solutions to some of the social challenges they face in their communities as migrants as well as young women.
The need for specific training for young women of the African Diaspora has been identified by the participating organizations in their needs assessment studies and through the evaluation and assessment of previously implemented projects. In our previous projects we have identified there is a particular need for creating an opportunity for African Diaspora young women and empower them to take the leadership role in the strive for social inclusion. 
In this regard, the main objectives of this project are;
1. To create a space where young women social workers with African heritage can come together and share their experiences about creative and sustainable social-entrepreneurship projects and further develop the skills and competencies needed for such projects. 
2. Build network of like-minded young women multipliers with the African background with similar experiences and missions to establish social enterprises that benefit communities.
3. To further build the online resource and capacity building portal and make it available for the African Diaspora young people in Europe. 
The expected outcome of the project is the training of 30 young social workers from the African Diaspora in skills and competencies needed for gender conscious social projects. The multipliers in this project in turn will assist in mainstreaming gender issues in projects undertaken by their sending organizations as well as promote Afro-young girls empowerment in their communities. The project will contribute to the social participation of migrant women and create opportunities for good practices exchange among similar migrant youth organizations.

CIRCLE PROCESSES BRIDGE FOR INCLUSION AND PEACEBUILDING
AFRICAN CENTRE FOR DEVELOPMENT AND RESEARCH LTD

Technological advancement revolutionized the way we communicate. Internet and social media altered the way and pace at which we communicate but in the process we also lost something. We lost sincere, honest and non-confrontational ways at approaching differences and how to discuss difficult and complex issues without confrontation or abuse or hateful or offensive rhetorics. Today, complex social issues like discrimination and xenophobia have been shortened to one hundred and forty characters in tweets but in years gone by, families gather around kitchen table or at meal to discuss complex issues with intergenerational dialogue within families. Circle process is a new way of bringing people together to engage and understand one another , strengthen bonds and solve community and social problems . This new way is really very old. It draws on ancient Native America tradition of using a talking piece, an object passes from person to person in a group and which grants the holder sole permission to speak. It combines this ancient tradition with contemporary concepts of democracy and inclusivity  in a complex, multicultural society with a view to promoting equality and democratization of space.

Circle process are being used in a variety of context. In schools they create a positive classroom climate and resolve behavioral  problems. In the workplace, they help to address conflict and in social services they help to develop a more organic support systems for people struggling to get their lives together. Furthermore, in communities . Circle process helps in community re-entry for those who had been incarcerated for a long time or on probation. The circle process in a story telling process. Every person has a story and every story has a lesson to offer. In the circle, people touch one another's lives by sharing stories that have meaning to them.

Peace-building and social re-engineering circles bring people of diverse backgrounds  together as equals to have honest exchanges about difficult social issues and sometimes painful experiences in an atmosphere of respect and concern for everyone.  In an increasing varied settings, peace-building circles are providing a space in which people from widely divergent perspectives can come together to speak candidly about conflict , pain and anger and leave those conversations feeling good about themselves and about others. The underlying philosophy of circles acknowledges that we are all in need of help and that helping others helps us at the same time. The participants of the circle benefits from the collective wisdom of everyone in the circle. Participants are not divided into givers and receivers ; everyone is both a giver and a receiver. Circles draw on the life experiences and wisdom of all participants to generate new understanding of the problem and new possibilities for solutions. Peace building circles bring together the ancient wisdom of community and contemporary value of respect for individuals gifts, needs , and differences in a process that:
- honors the presence and dignity of every participant
- Values the contribution of every participant
- emphasizes the connectedness of all things
-support emotional and spiritual expression
-gives equal voice to all

These project will utilize circle process to engage youth workers on complex social issues such has integration and inclusion and how to engage and maximize a multicultural space. The project will create atmosphere where everyone is respected, a process that allows everyone to get a chance to air their views on multiculturalism and integration. The process will re-establish the golden rule of equality where no person is more important than anyone else. These project will be facilitated through non-formal participatory methods which includes story telling and circle process of talking piece that is passed from one person to the other.

The project objectives includes; Training youth workers on
-Train 32 youth workers in circle process of peacemaking and peace-building
- Train youth workers on how to respond to painful experiences by breaking the cycle of violence
-Inclusive process to decision making
-How to manage disagreements within a team and community
-How to address an experience or situation that has harmed other people
-How to build an effective team
-How to leverage and appreciate diversity
-How to build a consensus decision making mechanism
-How to use story telling method to solve complex social issues
-How to use non-confrontational approach to transform conflict
-How to engage with diverse world views and intense feelings without anger or violence
-How to develop organic and inclusive leadership skills

There are 27 students of the College of Technical Engineering who will take part in the project. They have had five years in English language education, a graduated vocational education and at least one year work experience. As English is the international language for job related communication, the objective of this project is to improve the students’ English language skills. The project partner  Norwich Institute for Language Education (NILE) in Norwich, Great Britain offers the opportunity to our students to improve their English language skills, especially concerning the demands of a technical engineer.  This includes technical outings to local factories and staying with local families. Giving these students this extraordinary opportunity to immerse themselves in English language and culture in this way means that they will improve their language skills and gather job relevant experience in a member country of the European Union. This enables them to gain knowledge and also share it using a common language. Furthermore the students not only learn more about the way of life in a foreign country but also more about the different conditions and processes at workplaces. The students learn how to cope with standard situation in daily life by communicating in a foreign language. This experience and the ability to exchange knowledge in English will improve their chance of getting a better job in their home region and also sharpens the view for the necessity of being mobile within the borders of the European Union and beyond.

The focus of this project is on the following subject specific main topics:
- development of a technical product during the whole two weeks course,
- simulation of business meetings,
- taking part in discussions,
- writing and answering business letter,
- preparing subject related presentations in English
- giving presentations in front of an english-speaking audience. 
 
During all of these activities skilled Tutors from NILE observe the students progress to make sure that they are well prepared to work in an English speaking work environment.  
The basis for the activity is a Memerandum of Understanding and a learning agreement between the partner organisation (NILE), the students and the Technical College of Engineering in Memmingen. To adjust and fine tune the content of the course programme according to the students demands, a permanent contact between the involved organizations is essential.  The content of this learning agreement is furthermore the basis for the evaluation process of the activity to find out whether the previous made arrangement were achieved.   
Before the actual stay abroad the students will be prepared in pre-courses aside from regular English lessons to provide them with the necessary language skills as well as to help them to organise the trip. Even at this early stage of the whole activity there is a steady correspondence per email between NILE in Norwich and our school to make sure the course links to the language demands of the students successfully at any time of the project.
The courses, the excursions and the social programme in Norwich is organised by Nile itself as well as the homestay. The language course takes two weeks and consists of ten days with five hour lessons per day. At the beginning of the course the tutors check out the special needs of the student and divide them into two groups according to their English knowledge. At all-time two German teachers are at hand if their might occur any problem, like students become ill, etc. 
After the first five days of the course an interim evaluation will be made by filling out a questionnaire to ensure the quality of the activity and to enable the tutors at Nile to take action whether special needs are demanded. 
To practice the achieved language skills in real situations visits to factories like the Lotus Car Factory in Hethel or the IWM Aircraft museum in Duxford (where the students have to interact with staff members and managers) are made as well as trips to places and sights of cultural importance about which the students have to report and give presentations.
At the end of the course the students obtain a course specified certification as well as the Europass Mobility which will be signed by the two partners (NILE and the College of Technical Engineering).
Being back to their home country the students have to fill out a questionnaire to tell about the improvements and experiences they made and to critically evaluate the outcome of the activity.
The impressions of the whole trip, the experiences and improvements the students made will be told to the local media, narrated and described in the annual schoolbook and on the school’s homepage. Furthermore the Language Passport of the European Union will be filled out by the students themselves during English classes.
Finally the Europass Mobility will be handed out to the students at a special ceremony at school.

The Akademie der media GmbH, founded in 1993, is a private vocational school and an accredited academic institution with officially recognized degrees. The Stuttgart based academy trains around 300 experts and specialists in fields of business, media, education and technical product design. The project participants are trainees and retrainees of institutional apprenticeship in technical product design and media designers in the fields of audio/video as well as digital and print. The trainings concludes with an examination at the German Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK). At the time of their internship the project participants are in the 2nd or 3rd year of their training and have good English skills as well as excellent knowledge in their respective field of training. Because of their institutional education and professional projects, the participants are very familiar with the common software tools and trained in teamwork and independent working. 

Nowadays, employees need intercultural competence, language and communication skills to be successful on the job market. International exchanges, like internships, offer the possibility of education and development of skills and competences. The aim of the project is to sensitize the participants for intercultural issues and to enable them to integrate their acquired intercultural knowledge and skills into their everyday work. An internship abroad offers professional new insights and perspectives on their own working area as well as information about the foreign market and its business practices.

In order to offer all participants equal chances, we apply for the Erasmus+ grant. Thereby, also less affluent participants will be given the opportunity to go abroad. As many apprentices and retrainees as possible should be able to benefit from the advantages of an internship abroad.  

The detailed contents of the internships are defined in the contract with the respective companies and approved by the training managers. In view of the positive development on the trainees, the Akademe der media supports and promotes internships abroad and explicitly informs them already at registration about the importance of internships and the possibilities of implementation. An exposition of the project specific motivation for the stay abroad is expected. Sufficient knowledge of the English language is assumed and will be reviewed in English classes. Relevant criteria for the selection of participants are: motivation, cooperation, commitment, and above all the willingness to do an internship abroad. The participants will be personally advised and supported by the foreign advisor before and during the stay abroad. Furthermore, their supervisors and the supervisor in the company take care for the professional development of the interns during theri internship. The partner organization in the target country monitor compliance with the agreement and serve as a local contact in case of problems.

Project implementation: 
• Partner organizations report in the contractually agreed regular cycle 
• Partner organizations evaluate the participants not only with a reference and the Euro Pass mobility but create an individual evaluation by using a questionnaire 
• Participants keep a record book, which is signed by the internship company and will be checked and signed monthly by the training manager. 
• Return to Germany 
• Submission of internship documentation
• Follow-up and discussion


In the context of international internships both sides benefit: Participants gain international work experience and broaden their horizons, the internship companies can count on well-trained, innovative and dedicated interns. The future employers will benefit from the international expertise and highly topical education level of the participants. The Akademie der media sees the long-term benefits in the professional and international exchange with the project partners and participants.

We, the college for Occupations in the Service Industries Specialising in Social Management, are a Catholic private school of Caritas of the Diocese of Graz-Seckau. In our school there are 360 students and we are qualifying our students for a profession in the social and health field. In addition to a good educational background and language education, personality development and the promotion of social skills of our students are central. Important parts of our education are the various practical trainings. In these practical trainings our students get to know different areas of social work and also acquire social skills. Our students take the A-level exam and acquire practical, social and economic education. The objective of the project is the possibility to support 32 students to do their internship abroad. By participating in this mobility project, the students will expand their own abilities and skills, and hopefully gain financial support. At the time of the participation in this project our students already have at least 200 hours of practical work experience in an Austrian social institution and so they already have a good level of training. This allows the students to broaden their professional and personal horizons and to strengthen their language skills for working life. They also get to know a variety of innovative concepts and methods of social work in other European countries. The activities of the internship are different, depending on the participating organisations and include the following work areas for example: working with people with special needs, working with disadvantaged people, employment with children, rehabilitation of homeless people or administrative activities in a social institution. The duration of stay abroad is between 4 and 9 weeks. In general, all students of the third and fourth grade have the opportunity to apply for participation in this project. After personal interviews, feedback and agreement by the responsible person for the practical training, the students contact the participating organisation on their own. In the foreground is the self-organization of the students. If necessary they are always supported by teachers. During the internship abroad professional training and personal development are central. Students will improve their professional, social, personal and communication skills and acquire new ones. They will also establish networks for their future working lives and get to know different cultures. Through the internships our students will gain new experiences and impressions which they can use in Austria. They gain self-confidence and can deal with language barriers easily. All acquired skills are a personal gain for their future career. The stay abroad is recognized as an internship. The stories of the students from their internships and the smooth mobility of labor within the European Union will lead to more students planning to study abroad.

CONTEXT

'Building Sustainable Communities with VET 3' expands on two previous KA1 mobility projects that brings together B3st’s ambitions in providing relevant placements at organisations who work sustainably in communities and education in Seville, Spain and Faro, Portugal. It recognises the need for participants to gain work experience that is increasingly difficult to obtain in order to develop their career. The placements will add great value by offering a supportive environment for participants to gain new industry insights, become proficient in a language other than English and appreciate another European culture. 

PARTICIPANT PROFILE

The project will accommodate a total of 72 participants over two years. They will typically be learners working towards vocational qualifications in the field of community development and training and education. We anticipate they will be between the ages of 18 and 25 and come from various backgrounds, often with limited opportunities to gain relevant work experience in their chosen field.  The three month mobility will be formally recognised through Europass mobility documents and certificates from upon successful completion of their vocational course.

OBJECTIVES

Our main aim is to provide VET learners with relevant work experience in community engagement and education to enhance and develop their careers. We aim to give participants:

• A practical understanding of work at a relevant organisation that engages communities using a sustainable approach
• Enhanced employability skills that demonstrate workplace experience and adaptability 
• Personal and professional development with intercultural and linguistic skills
• The opportunity to network and build up contacts in the relevant field
• The platform to progress in their chosen career or embark upon further education in their sector

ACTIVITIES

The main activity involves a work placement of three months at a range of community-focused organisations in either Seville or Faro. This will be complemented by linguistic support from qualified tutors and a programme of cultural and social activities, including organised language exchanges. The participants will be supported throughout the lifetime of the project with clearly defined stages, from mobility preparation to evaluation. Our mentoring and monitoring processes will aim to address the development and well-being of participants during their placement while informing project evaluation. 

METHODOLOGY

The project’s methodology provides a framework to support VET learners in developing skills acquired in the workplace as they work alongside experienced professionals in their chosen sector. Through our experience with past European mobility projects and our employer partnerships, we have developed and applied appropriate processes and instruments to ensure the project can be effectively managed and evaluated while providing support to participants for their personal and professional progression. 

IMPACT

We anticipate that the project will make a positive impact on all its 72 participants by giving them the opportunity to develop professional and personal skills at a relevant work placement. Based on past projects, the experience will increase the participant's’ employment prospects while also giving them confidence to apply for work across Europe. It is expected that at least two thirds of participants will move into suitable employment upon completion of the placement, with a further one fifth progressing into continued related training. 

The three month placement in Seville and Faro, together with linguistic support, should increase the participants’ language proficiency by one CEFR level. The project will also impact on our partners by building their capacity to participate in further Erasmus+ programmes and European projects. The focus on sustainable communities should encourage participants and partners to consider and continue building a sustainable future for European society, reflecting Europe 2020 objectives. 

SUSTAINABILITY

Project outcomes will feed back into our own work as a training provider, our established partner relationships and employer networks, such as the Brighton Sustainable Business Network. It will benefit our development of European-centred vocational training and planned KA1 and KA2 projects in the field. Our relationship with partners that have wider networks will facilitate dissemination activities with the intention of building sustainability into professional approaches and organisation operations; closing the gap between VET provision and the world of work; and fostering a more informed understanding of the needs of jobseekers and employers in community development.

The INTERNATIONALIZATION AND INCORPORATION OF THE EUROPEAN PERSPECTIVE to the educational offer of the centers, is part of the "European Development Plan" of the Consortium. It leads the formulation of the Project "YOUNG EUROLAB IV", forth edition of the projects approved in the 2014, 2016 and 2017 calls .

The Project is promoted by the Mobility Consortium composed of:
- Municipal Institute of Employment and Training for Business (IMEFE). Coordinator and Sending Organisation, Jaén
- Virgen del Carmen, VET School. Sending Organisation, Jaén
- El Valle, VET School. Sending Organisation, Jaén
- Santa María de los Apóstoles. VET School. Sending Organisation, Jaén 
- San Juan Bosco. VET School. Sending Organisation, Jaén 
- Auringis. VET School. Sending Organisation, Jaén 
- Las Fuentezuelas. VET School. Sending Organisation, Jaén

The project starts from the idea that PERMANENT LEARNING and MOBILITY should be a reality in our educational community. The EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT PLAN OF THE CONSORTIUM (EDP) responds to common needs identified among students and professionals of the Vocational Training sector, in the city of Jaén. It will give higher rigor and consistency to the actions included in the Project.

STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES:
- Achieve synergies in the area of project management and optimize the management of the resources and processes associated with mobilities.
- Strengthen collaboration between VET Schools and the City Council.
- To improve the employability level of the participants.

GENERAL OBJECTIVES:
- Ensure the optimal levels of the quality of the stays.
- "MOBILITY" concept, as an effective instrument for the development of key skills and competencies of the participants
- Increase the attractiveness of educational proposals.
- Prevent the radicalization of attitudes.

SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES
- To achieve an employment percentage higher than 50%.
- Offer 15 mobilities for 15 days for students of the first year in VET studies. Training periods in companies in ITALY (VET SHORT).
- Offer 32 mobilities experiences of 95 days, for students of the second year of their training courses (obligatory training in companies – FCT). Recent Graduates of VET Schools and Recent Graduates from the Training Specialities leading to Professional Certificates (taught by IMEFE). Internships in ITALY (12) CZECH REPUBLIC (12) and IRELAND (12). VETPLONG ERASMUS PRO).
- Organise 16 mobilities experiences for the STAFF in IRELNAD (8) and THE NEDERLANDS (8). In order to know the educational system of this country and open new mobilities in future Erasmus + projects. JOB – SHADOWING FOR THE STAFF.

NEEDS TO COVER:
- STUDENTS AND RECENT GRADUATEDS: acquisition and development of skills and competences (technical skills, autonomy, problem solving, responsibility, initiative, language skills, etc.) as well as positive attitudes (effort, flexibility, respect, tolerance).
- STAFF: motivation, networking with professionals from other European countries, analysis of "competition at European level" as a didactic methodology for the motivation of vocational students and the achievement of excellence.

KEY ACTIVITIES:
- DESIGN of the stays: profile and number of participants, duration, selection of destinations and European partners, logistics, identification of host companies, definition of expected learning outcomes.
- FOLLOW-UP of the stays: tutoring equipment, coordination system and communication channels between tutors.
- EVALUATION: The ultimate objective is the evaluation process is to identify aspects to be improved in the field of:
* The quality of the design of the mobilities.
* The Logistics.
* Attitudes and learning processes of participants.
* Satisfaction levels
We will use various TOOLS: Direct observation, follow-up meetings, questionnaires for participants and companies.
- DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS: optimization of the IMPACT of the communication actions carried out and review, where appropriate, of the Consortium Communication Plan.
- IMPACT OF THE PROJECT: to what extent the results obtained are due exclusively to the effect of Mobility (NET IMPACT) and which are the result of the addition of various causes: Language level, employability, skills development and professional skills.
De Madrid a Europa, Erasmus+ FP. Proyecto de Fundación Montemadrid con la participación de centros de la Comunidad de Madrid

The project ‘From Madrid to Europe, Erasmus + Vocational Training’, arises from a common interest: the internationalization of Madrid’s youth people and of the educational centers of the region of Madrid. After the development of a first project in Dublin of 31 mobilities, a second one with more destinations, sending institutions and mobilities and a third one that strengthens all the lessons learnt in the previous one, the new project consolidates the work done and the cooperation with the General Directorate of Vocational Training in the region of Madrid (DG FP). 
The new figure ErasmusPRO has been added and the number of destinations has grown on to recently-acceded to the EU countries as Slovenia, which also allows the increase of the number of ordinary mobilities (84, including 4 of long-term mode) and of special needs (8), as well as the educational centers/sending institutions members of the consortium (18) which find it difficult managing mobilities on their own.
The project’s objectives for the students are, therefore: improve their employability with the acquirement of new technical skills, improvement of social and language skills and self-confidence and matureness gaining because of the unique experience that staying abroad means. And for the sending institutions: facilitate their participation in European mobility projects with the corresponding internationalization of their work, as well as amplify and diversify their educational offer. 
The new project keeps growing in terms of number of mobilities and destination countries. It consists of 90 mobilities for students to make an internship period in companies based in United Kingdom, Ireland, Italy,  Slovenia, Czech Republic and Portugal (without a training period): 50 of Intermediate Vocational Training students to make their module of Training in Working Centers, 30 more and shorter for students of Intermediate Vocational Training on their 1st or 2nd year of study, 4 for long-term mobilities of the type of ErasmusPRO and 8 more for students of Intermediate Vocational Training and Professional Programs with special needs. Students will be given preference but recent graduates will be allowed to take part in the project as well. It consists as well in 14 vacancies for accompanying people for each travel flow during the first days of stay, and, of course, for the 8 students with special needs, considering the previously acquired experience and the fact that most of the students have never been abroad and/or come from deprived areas. 
Activities. The project has a clear intention of continuity and consolidation of the three previous ones. The DG FP and Foundation have agreed to maintain 15 of the sending institutions of the current project and to add 4 more in order to cover the placements offer. The Mobility Comitee will periodically meet and Foundation will draw up a record of the agreements reached. Informational and of the project’s dissemination talks are foreseen (with previous participants) in each sending institution. The participation in the selection process will be open to all students that meet the criteria stablished in the Call Bases that will be agreed, approved, and published by the Comitee. At least 86 participants will receive language training from the OLS and pedagogical and cultural talks are also foreseen. The educational plan will be agreed between the sending and hosting mentors and stablished in the Learning Agreement document. The internship monitoring will be made in a direct and periodic way by the two mentors, the partner institutions, and the Foundation itself. Project management in each stage will be conducted by Foundation. At the end of the internship periods a final evaluation of each student will be made and supporting documents will be issued (Europass Mobility Document and Certificate of Attendance).
Methology. Foundation will maintain the professional relationship with the partner institutions that will provide host companies and will manage accommodation, insurance deals and journeys (travel days). 
Expected results and impact. Complement the students training, consolidate the links with partners, internationalization for all (participants, sending institutions, coordinator, etc.) and support the European integration of recently-acceded countries developing mobilities in destinations as Slovenia.
Long Term Benefits. Strengthen the institutional and strategic relations with DG FP, European dimension awareness of the sending and receiving institutions, and the most important one for all consortium members: improve the capacity of the participant to find a job that satisfies their professional, financial and of personal development needs.

Sewing a network: electronic textiles in educational making workshops

For almost a decade, the maker movement has been making its own may into non-formal education. Educators and researchers have been talking about the role of making activities in learning; they highlight the potential for project-based and hands-on approach to boost youth interest for inquiry and learning, to re-activate them from a social, psychological, professional point of view.
One popular strand of making activities in the context of non formal education involve experimenting with computer
programming, electronics, and robotics.
Typically, girls are much less prone to participate in such initiatives than boys, mainly due to the negative stereotypes they nurture towards scientific and technical disciplines. Thus, the great promise of the maker movement to democratize access to making as well as to its progressive spirit and philosophy are to be reconsidered in the face of evidence. If we believe that making activities and maker identities are crucial for empowerment, then it is our job to set up situations whereby all learners have the opportunity and will to engage.
E-textiles promises to be the trojan horse that will enable girls to fully benefit from making activities and the maker  movement. By combining fashion with electronic and computer programming, e-textiles offer female youth expanded access to materials and tools, resulting in opportunities to take on project leadership roles in highly technical areas.

Project Objectives

● Innovate youth work by introducing new practices based on the combination of crafting
textiles with computer programming and electronics
● Exchange on tinkering as an emerging pedagogical approach, especially crafting
e-textiles as a way to boost female participation in non formal educational activities
● Sensitize youth workers to initiatives around electronic DIY and digital culture

Project Activities

Participants will partake in a week-long training on e-textiles, in view of jumpstarting this practice in their own
professional settings. The training will take place in France.
The main activities of the course will be:
- Introduction to electronic DIY for youth work purposes, via the Arduino open-source prototyping board
- Introduction to e-textiles
- Production of e-textiles projects, working in groups
- Debate on how to assess making activities and monitor learning outcomes. Up-to-date tools and methods
conceived specifically to serve this purpose will be presented and experimented.

A second mobility activity within the framework of this project will take place in Romania, where participants will continue to explore the practice of making in educational settings.
At this stage, participants will:
- Meet with the local maker community (Hatch hackerspace and Nod Makerspace, in Bucharest)
- Learn about constructivist teaching methods (teaching methods based on hands on, immersive, participative
approach, project based learning)
- Explore initiatives aiming to support the integration of the maker attitude in the field of education run at
international scale
- Practice maker education in a makerspace/fablab setting
- Discuss extra thoughts on building girl-inclusive maker workshops.

Learning Outcomes

As a result of the training course participants will be able to:
● Get youngsters involved in initiatives on electronic DIY, in particular about e-textiles
● Initiate and supervise activities targeting youth on the topics of e-textiles
● Identify and seize opportunities to constantly innovate youth workers’ professional
practices
● Encourage female youth participation in educational activities on technical topics.

Target public

● Anyone with a passion/interest in digital technologies, and interested in youth work
● Individuals active in the promotion of DIY and/or digital culture interested in running educational activities
targeting young people
● Youth workers with an experience in non formal digital education or willing to launch educational workshops
on this topic
● Youth workers seeking ways to boost participation of female youth in educational activities on ICT

Through this project we want to initiate youth practitioners to youth work practices that combine music making with digital technologies and digital DIY.

There are several ways of combing music making with digital technologie, some which include creating electronic musical instruments, recording and devices and amplifiers, music making with computer softwares specifically conceived for this purpose.

We believe that by embedding digital technologies within non formal music education, it is possible to produce the kind of learning outcomes mentioned above, whilst at the same time addressing a number of issues related, notably, to improving young people’s digital literacy.

Over the course of a week, participants from 4 different countries will gather to experiment digital technica and tools pertaining to digital music making, in view of improving and/or developing the educational offer for non formal activities targeting youth, in their respective professional contexts. 

The project’s operational objectives can be summed up as follows:

Exchange on tinkering as an emerging pedagogical approach, especially the methodology mixing arts, music and technology
Sensitize youth workers to initiatives around electronic DIY and digital culture, initiatives that can encourage youth to engage with local maker communities (ex. makerfest, maker faires, etc.)
share competences, anecdotes, and experiences between the participating parties on the topic of digitally enabled non formal education/youth work

The main activities of the course will be:

- Electronics and sound production
an introduction to electronic prototyping via the crafting of sound making devices 

- musical Instrument building
using the facilities and the machinery available at Pralnia makerspace, participants will create individually or in groups, diy electronic musical instruments

- Electronics and sound amplification 
Different workshops will be implemented to introduce participants to some of the most common technologies available to produce DIY sound amplifiers. 

- Digital music making
participants will use an assortment of computer softwares for production of sound, and will craft a MIDI controller (a device that registers data and send it to a computer which in turn triggers sounds and  controls parameters of an electronic music performance) based on an electronic board available on the market and generally employed for educational purposes (makey makey). 

- Recording and editing 
creation of DIY audio recording devices

- Exchange and brainstorming exchange between participants of good practices about music education, digital music making practices with young people, and also educational making activities and digital DIY. exchange on reducing the environmental impact of digital youth work and designing cost effective solutions for digital youth work

at the end of the training, participants will showcase their productions and learning via a practical workshops on digital music making with local youth as well as a public concert/jam session at the local german theatre.

LEARNING OUTCOMES

participants are expected to acquire technical competences in the domain of computer science and electronics, confidence in delivering digital music making workshops for young people. the project shall have an impact on the professional practices of participants, on their ability to pursue personal, professional ambitions, and on their understanding of interculturality and groups of people from different european countries. 

TARGET PUBLIC

● Anyone with a passion/interest in digital
technologies, and interested in youth work

● Individuals active in the promotion of DIY and/or digital culture interested in running educational activities targeting young people 

● Youth workers with an
experience in non formal digital education or willing to launch educational workshops on this topic 

●Youth workers seeking ways to boost participation of female youth in educational activities on ICT

Digital literacy plays a major role in modern-day citizenship and modern life in general, therefore all young people not only need to have technological skills, but also a healthy attitude and mindset towards technology in their future work and everyday life. Youth work should be able to respond to these needs accordingly by having skilled workers that are familiar with on-line tools, and who are also able to raise critical questions about technology. As the primary role of youth work is to assist young people through their transition into adulthood, we have to bring our focus on helping youth to find a balance between on-line and off-line worlds. Through our conversations with Partner Organisations, Youth Work Practitioners and Young People, and by taking into consideration the challenging context of Youth Work in Europe today we have identified an urgent need to contribute to developing digital youth work competences of youth work practitioners and young people, and also the need to put emphasis on critically analysing social media. As all Partner Organisations are using digital youth work approach in their practices and have years of experiences addressing hate speech online, we are keen to explore different digital tools and digital youth work approach and to challenge the issues such as cyber bullying, hate speech on-line, social exclusion etc. that digitisation have brought upon young people.

The main objectives of 'Re-Naturing' project is to explore Digital Youth Work Approach and to bring focus on critical analysis of social media through the perspectives of youth work practitioners, young people and youth organisations. Specific objectives of 'Re-Naturing' for each of the groups are: 
* Youth Work practitioners: to support their development of knowledge and skills for Digital Youth Work, and to foster an attitude of critically analysing social media; also to enhance passion and competences for International Youth Work.
* Young People: to provide a safe space for critical discussions about social media and technology; skills of digital literacy; and experiences of re-connecting with nature and people.
* Youth Organisations: to create opportunities for up-skilling staff and volunteers with Digital Youth Work competences as a response to challenging the context of youth digitisation. 

'Re-Naturing' project has three Mobility Activities: 
A 1. Youth Workers Mobility (September 2018 Ireland)
A 2. Advance Planning Visit (September 2018 Georgia)
A 3. Youth Mobility Activity (October 2018 Georgia)

Through their learning process Youth Work Practitioners will come to understand how digitisation is shaping and changing 'old school' youth work context. They will know how young people communicate in digital environments and what supports they need to be able to react to hate speech, cyber bullying and other unwanted behaviour online. They will gain an ability to encourage young people to make informed decisions about on-line image and activities.Thus, will be able to asses and to understand digital literacy level of each young person that they work with in order to support him/her. Youth Work Practitioners will know how to challenge young people to think critically about social media and digital content. Practitioners will establish appropriate professional boundaries in their on-line relationships with young people, while reflecting on their personal youth worker's digital identity and will learn how to use different digital tools. As a result of these skills and knowledge gain they will feel more confident and 'up to speed' in the context of digital youth work.They will find easier to connect with young people as a result of better understand young peoples on-line relationships and on-line realities. 

Through their learning experiences participants will be able to articulate personal position in terms of digitisation, and become actively involved in the process that is shaping our societies.Young People will be safer on-line, as they will know how to address the issues of cyber bullying and hate speech, how to protect their digital identity, and how to assess risks on-line. They will make an informed choices about the life they want to live on social media and the self-image they create on-line. Through intercultural learning experiences Young People will become more open to different cultures and will appreciate diversity. They will feel confident and be able to address difficult life situations as a source of learning. Young People will know how to find 'outside-the-box' solutions therefore the quality of their lives will improve. Additional sets of new skills will develop through the youth exchange, such as facilitation, public speaking, group work and English language which will improve their employ-ability. Also, ability to relate to people from various backgrounds, cultures and natural environment will reflect positively in personal relationships with people around.
Higher education student and staff mobility project
This is a higher education student and staff mobility project, please consult the website of the organisation to obtain additional details.

As a vocational business school the Friedrich-List-Berufskolleg cooperates with regional internationally active companies. That is why internationalization is of high priority for us and for this reason there are several different activities and developments at our school to further our internationalization.
In 2018 our Erasmus+ mobility project in England for trainees will again be a central part our strategy of internationalization. Meanwhile the number of dual courses of vocational education has grown to eight. Like in recent years our students will take part in a four-week period of practical training while living in host families. This large-scale project will strengthen not only the mobility but also the international awareness of our students.
In the full-time courses of education students of our school have the opportunity to get support for periods of practical training abroad, including certification with the Europass Mobility. In the long term our school also plans to start an practical training.
A further component of our school’s strategy of internationalization is an exchange of retail students with France, supported by the Deutsch-Französisches Sekretariat. Preparations are in progress for this programme.
In 2017 our school took part in the DAAD programme “Europa macht Schule”. Students from the international remedial classes learned from visiting spanish and portugueses students more about Europe in a fascinating way. This successfull project will take part in 2018, too. 
Moreover, there will be field excursions for full-time and part-time students to Brussels, Prague and Strasbourg at the Friedrich-List-Berufskolleg in 2018.
Foreign language teaching is valued highly at our school. Especially English is promoted by lessons at different levels according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Such a course system has been successfully implemented in the English classes for retail as well as wholesale and foreign trade students. Furthermore, trainees at our school can choose to take part in additional business English courses to have their skills certified by the London Chamber of Commerce and Industry. This offer of foreign language learning certification is open to all classes.
In English lessons and politics classes European topics are being taught, especially in preparation of the students’ work placements in England. In English and German lessons the students are also taught to deal with Europass CVs so that they can competitively present their skills on the European job market.
Another qualification to be gained which can increase the students’ job finding opportunities nationally and internationally is the European Computer Driving Licence. The Friedrich-List-Berufskolleg is a certified ECDL test centre.
Besides, at the Friedrich-List-Berufskolleg students can learn to look out for fairness in international trade as there is a students’ café project called “Fair Café” in which they mostly sell fair trade products from developing countries to other students.
To facilitate the integration of foreign students in Germany and at our school we now offer several international remedial classes for youths without a certificate of secondary education and devoid of or with only very little German language skills. Because of the increased amount of refugees, this course of studies has become a main focus for our college.
